June 10, 2001: Fiction
CHOSEN PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $26.95.) Lucas Davenport pursues
a kinky art history professor who has discovered that he likes to kill women.
ON THE STREET WHERE YOU LIVE, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster,
$26.) A defense lawyer finds herself haunted by two murders that took place 110
years apart.
BACK WHEN WE WERE GROWNUPS, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $25.) A 53-year-
old woman, the head of an unruly extended family in Baltimore, tries to recover her
"original self."
DREAMCATCHER, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $28.) In the woods of Maine, four
hunters who have been friends since boyhood encounter a disoriented stranger
and a dangerous creature from another world.
A PAINTED HOUSE, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) The experiences of
a 7-year-old boy whose parents live and work in the cotton fields of Arkansas.
A COMMON LIFE, by Jan Karon. (Viking, $24.95.) Celebrating the wedding of
Father Tim Kavanagh and Cynthia Coppersmith; the sixth "Mitford Years" book.
DEATH IN HOLY ORDERS, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $25.) Cmdr. Adam Dalgliesh
investigates the death of a powerful businessman's son at a small theological
college in England.
THE LAST TIME THEY MET, by Anita Shreve. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) Two writers
who once had a passionate affair meet years later at a literary festival.
LONE EAGLE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $26.95.) A woman is reunited with
the love of her life, a legendary aviator who was Charles Lindbergh's protege.
CHOKE, by Chuck Palahniuk. (Doubleday, $24.95.) A medical school dropout who
earns his living at a dreary Colonial American theme park comes up with a novel
way of supplementing his income.
THE SUMMERHOUSE, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $24.95.) Three women, each
of whom is about to turn 40, are given the chance to rewrite their pasts.
THE BONESETTER'S DAUGHTER, by Amy Tan. (Putnam, $25.95.) A Chinese-
American woman struggles to understand her family and herself.
1ST TO DIE, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $26.95.) Four women -- a
homicide inspector, a medical examiner, an assistant district attorney and a
journalist -- search for a killer who is stalking newlyweds.
THE COLD SIX THOUSAND, by James Ellroy. (Knopf, $25.95.) The American
political underbelly of the 1960's, as experienced by a mob lawyer, a hired killer
Non-Fiction
JOHN ADAMS, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) A biography of
the country's first vice president and second president.
GHOST SOLDIERS, by Hampton Sides. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The story of a
United States Army plan to rescue prisoners of war (including survivors of the
Bataan death march) in the Philippines in early 1945.
AN ALBUM OF MEMORIES, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $29.95.) More
personal histories from members of "the greatest generation."
FOLEY IS GOOD, by Mick Foley. (ReganBooks/ HarperCollins, $26.95.) The
second behind-the-scenes memoir by the professional wrestler known as
Mankind.
STOLEN LIVES, by Malika Oufkir and Mich√®le Fitoussi. (Talk Miramax/Hyperion,
$24.) A Moroccan woman recalls the 20 years she spent in a desert jail.
NAPALM & SILLY PUTTY, by George Carlin. (Hyperion, $22.95.) The comedian
offers opinions on everything from God to pets to the Lone Ranger's laundry.
SEABISCUIT, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $24.95.) A biography of the
great horse whose career culminated in a 1938 match race with the Triple Crown
winner War Admiral.
THE DIRT, by Motley Crue with Neil Strauss. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins,
$27.95.) The confessions of "the world's most notorious rock band."
FRENCH LESSONS, by Peter Mayle. (Knopf, $24.) A celebration of the
gastronomic pleasures available throughout France.
IN HARM'S WAY, by Doug Stanton. (Holt, $25.) The sinking of the cruiser
Indianapolis in World War II and the story of its survivors.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The author
tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
FOUNDING BROTHERS, by Joseph J. Ellis. (Knopf, $26.) A historian's study of
the intertwined lives of the nation's founders.
AT ANY COST, by Bill Sammon. (Regnery, $27.95.) A reporter for The
Washington Times describes "how Al Gore tried to steal the election."
NICKEL AND DIMED, by Barbara Ehrenreich. (Metropolitan/Holt, $23.) A social
critic reports on what it was like to become a member of the working poor.
WHEN YOU COME TO A FORK IN THE ROAD, TAKE IT! by Yogi Berra with
Dave Kaplan. (Hyperion, $16.95.) Reminiscences and aphorisms from the Yankee
